div.p: One theory I saw on Tumblr (might have been kontextmaschine or balioc) to explain both the depths of hatred that some young people feel towards Boomers and the fact that a large subset of Boomers seems to be invisible:

When people say "Boomer", they're not talking about ex-miners or farmers or factory workers who haven't had steady work since the mine/farm/factory closed in 1987. They're talking about people who were born into middle-class or higher families in the suburbs, went to college, got a white-collar or creative job, racked up income via pensions and investments, and retired with a wealth of assets. That's not a large group of people all things considered. But it's the group that millennials from the same background saw becoming as their birthright. They went to good schools, they got liberal arts degrees, so where's their well-paying creative-field job? Hence the special venom, and the studied ignoring of whoever doesn't fit the 'rich spoiled Boomer' archetype.
